articles.title: Spain bids €400 million to host mega telescope at risk in US budget cuts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01230-9New Canary Islands home could save controversial Thirty Meter Telescope first proposed for Hawaii.
articles.content:
The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT), a major international project long slated for construction in Hawaii, might be getting a new home.

Last month, the administration of US president Donald Trump announced plans to abandon further support for the telescope, as part of its proposals to slash by half funding for the US National Science Foundation (NSF), which has until now supported the telescope’s design.

Now the Spanish government has pitched to bring the giant facility to La Palma, in Spain’s Canary Islands — and backed up the effort with a pledge to contribute €400 million (US$470 million).

“Spain reinforces its commitment as a refuge for science, betting on excellent research and technological innovation,” wrote the Spanish minister for science and innovation, Diana Morant, on X, as she announced the funding on 23 July.

According to a statement from her ministry, Morant has already submitted a formal proposal to host the telescope to the TMT board, which would have to back such a move for it to go ahead. The TMT was “at risk of paralysis”, added the minister.

A new Generation

The telescope’s 30-metre light-collecting mirror would dwarf those of today’s best optical telescopes. It is one of three telescopes of this scale now under development, and which will allow astronomers to study the cosmos with unprecedented resolution. La Palma has long been mentioned as a back-up location for the telescope, should its development stall on Hawaii’s Mauna Kea mountain, where activists had opposed its construction. A disadvantage of the Spanish site is that, at 2,250 metres high, La Palma is lower than Mauna Kea‘s 4,050 metres. This means the telescope would have more atmosphere to see through, affecting the quality of the observations.

articles.personality_title: Spain offers €400 million to save giant telescope project
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) is a huge international astronomy project originally planned for Hawaii. It’s designed to be one of the world’s most powerful telescopes, helping scientists explore the universe in amazing detail. But recent US government budget cuts threatened to stop the project.

**What happened**
After the US announced it would cut funding for the telescope, Spain stepped in with an offer to host the TMT on the island of La Palma in the Canary Islands. Spain proposed a €400 million bid to build the telescope there, giving the project a new home and new hope.

**Impact**
This move means the telescope can keep moving forward, preserving valuable international cooperation in science. Hosting the TMT in Spain will also boost local science and technology, while helping astronomers continue their important work exploring space.

**What's next step**
The telescope’s stakeholders will now review Spain’s offer and decide how to proceed. If approved, construction could begin on La Palma, marking a fresh start for this exciting project outside the US.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Spain’s bold offer shows how international teamwork can protect and advance vital science projects even when faced with setbacks.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'Espagne propose 400 millions d'euros pour sauver un gigantesque projet de télescope
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le télescope de trente mètres (TMT) est un grand projet international d’astronomie initialement prévu à Hawaï. Il est conçu pour être l’un des télescopes les plus puissants au monde, aidant les scientifiques à explorer l’univers avec une grande précision. Mais des coupes budgétaires récentes aux États-Unis ont menacé de stopper le projet.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Après l’annonce des États-Unis de réduire le financement du télescope, l’Espagne est intervenue en proposant d’accueillir le TMT sur l’île de La Palma, aux Canaries. L’Espagne a présenté une offre de 400 millions d’euros pour construire le télescope là-bas, offrant un nouveau foyer et un nouvel espoir au projet.

**Impact**
Cette initiative permet au télescope de continuer à avancer, en préservant une précieuse coopération scientifique internationale. Accueillir le TMT en Espagne stimulera également les sciences et technologies locales, tout en aidant les astronomes à poursuivre leur travail important d’exploration spatiale.

**Prochaine étape**
Les parties prenantes du télescope vont maintenant étudier l’offre espagnole et décider de la suite. Si elle est acceptée, la construction pourrait commencer à La Palma, marquant un nouveau départ pour ce projet passionnant hors des États-Unis.

**À retenir en une phrase**
L’offre audacieuse de l’Espagne montre comment le travail d’équipe international peut protéger et faire avancer des projets scientifiques essentiels malgré les difficultés.
articles.personality_title_es: España ofrece 400 millones de euros para salvar un gigantesco proyecto de telescopio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El Telescopio de Treinta Metros (TMT) es un gran proyecto internacional de astronomía originalmente planeado para Hawái. Está diseñado para ser uno de los telescopios más potentes del mundo, ayudando a los científicos a explorar el universo con gran detalle. Pero los recientes recortes presupuestarios en Estados Unidos amenazaron con detener el proyecto.

**Lo que pasó**
Tras el anuncio de Estados Unidos de reducir el financiamiento para el telescopio, España intervino ofreciendo acoger el TMT en la isla de La Palma, en las Islas Canarias. España propuso una oferta de 400 millones de euros para construir el telescopio allí, dando un nuevo hogar y una nueva esperanza al proyecto.

**Impacto**
Este movimiento significa que el telescopio puede seguir avanzando, preservando una valiosa cooperación internacional en ciencia. Alojar el TMT en España también impulsará la ciencia y tecnología local, mientras ayuda a los astrónomos a continuar su importante trabajo de explorar el espacio.

**Próximo paso**
Los interesados en el telescopio revisarán ahora la oferta de España y decidirán cómo proceder. Si se aprueba, la construcción podría comenzar en La Palma, marcando un nuevo comienzo para este emocionante proyecto fuera de EE.UU.

**Conclusión en una frase**
La audaz oferta de España muestra cómo el trabajo en equipo internacional puede proteger y avanzar proyectos científicos vitales incluso frente a dificultades.
